note.p: John Jones Pettus was Mississippi's governor during the first three years of the Civil War.

Born in Wilson County, Tennessee, on October 9, 1813, Pettus moved to Limestone County, Alabama, as a child. In 1835, he moved to Mississippi and eventually began a law practice in Scooba, Mississippi. He married Permelia Winston in the 1840s. She passed away in 1857, and in 1861 Pettus married Susan Hewell.

Pettus began pursuing a political career in the mid-1840s, first serving as a state representative for Kemper County. He won a state Senate election in 1848 and by 1853 had risen to president of the Mississippi Senate. Then, in January 1854, Governor Henry S. Foote resigned in protest before Governor-elect John J. McRae was inaugurated. Pettus’ position in the Senate placed him next in line to fill the governor’s vacancy, and he was sworn in as Mississippi’s interim executive on January 7, 1854. He served in that role for only three days, before McRae was inaugurated on January 10.

Pettus won the governor’s election in 1859. By that time, he had become a notable secessionist. He advocated for the creation of an independent Confederacy dedicated to preserving slavery. When Abraham Lincoln was elected president in 1860, Pettus called forth a special legislative session in Mississippi and pressed state representatives to hold a secession convention. His efforts succeeded, as such convention assembled in January 1861 and voted in support of secession, declaring the State of Mississippi out of the Union. Pettus won reelection for governor in 1861 and served until his term ended in 1863. Mississippi’s Constitution had a two-term limit for the governor’s office, leaving Pettus unable to run again. He took a commission as a colonel in the Mississippi State Troops and served until the end of the war. Shortly thereafter, Pettus moved to Arkansas. He applied for a presidential pardon according to President Andrew Johnson’s Reconstruction policies, but was denied three times.
Pettus died of pneumonia on January 25, 1867. He is buried in Flat Bayou Cemetery, Jefferson County, Arkansas.

note.p: LeRoy Pope Walker was the first Secretary of War for the Confederate States of America.

Born on February 7, 1817, near Huntsville, Alabama, Walker received a private education before attending the University of Alabama and then the University of Virginia in the 1830s. He studied law and became an attorney before turning 21 years old. Coming from an influential family in Alabama, Walker held various public offices in the state in the 1840s, including serving as a circuit court judge.

Walker was an outspoken advocate of secession during the 1850s. Following Alabama’s secession in early 1861, Confederate president Jefferson Davis appointed Walker as Secretary of War. He also served as a secession commissioner from Alabama to Tennessee, in an effort to draw the latter state into the Confederacy. Among his most notable actions as a Confederate cabinet member were public speeches in which he made bold—and very wrong—predictions about the fate of the Confederacy. Early in his tenure he rejected the prospect of large war between the Union and the Confederacy, famously claiming he would wipe up all the blood spilled with his handkerchief. After the firing on Fort Sumter and the sudden rush to war, Walker made another speech prophesizing a Confederate flag waving over the White House in Washington, D.C. By the late summer of 1861 he suffered health problems from work-related stress. President Davis offered him the opportunity to travel to Europe as a representative of the Confederate government, but Walker declined. He stepped down as secretary in September 1861, but accepted a commission as brigadier general in the Confederacy army and (despite no military experience) commanded troops at military forts and posts in Alabama. He resigned his commission in March 1862, but returned to the military in April 1864 to serve as a military judge.

Following the Civil War, Walker was active in opposing Republican Reconstruction in Alabama, including serving as president of the Alabama constitutional convention in 1875 that overturned Reconstruction policies. Following Reconstruction, he worked as an attorney in Alabama. He died on August 23, 1884. Walker was married twice, first to a Miss Hopkins who passed away after bearing him two children. He then married Eliza Dickson Pickett and had three more children. Walker is buried in Maple Hill Cemetery in Huntsville, Alabama.

Located in Hinds County, Jackson was founded in 1822 and serves as one of two county seats of Hinds County and the state capital of Mississippi. (Britannica)

Currently an independent city, Richmond was founded in 1737 in what was Henrico County at the time of founding and was incorporated on 1742. It became the state capital of Virginia in 1779. During the American Civil War, Richmond also served as capital of the Confederacy. On July 9, 1902, Richmond became an independent city. (Wikipedia; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)

gloss.p: The act of beginning to fight or a period of time in a war, military engagements are also referred to as battles or skirmishes. Battles are fights between armed forces, and usually describe singular events that occur over the course of hours or a few days. Skirmishes are smaller fights, usually between a small number of soldiers that occur unexpectedly, last only a few minutes or a few hours, and take place away from the main area of fighting.

There were approximately 10,500 engagements during the American Civil War. Fifty of them were major battles, while another one hundred were notable engagements. The rest were small battles or skirmishes. (Cambridge Dictionary; American Battlefield Trust)

catDesc.term: Military Engagements--Fort Donelson, Battle of, Tenn., 1862

gloss.p: The Battle of Fort Donelson was fought on February 11 – 16, 1862 in Stewart County, Tennessee between Union land and naval forces commanded by Brig. Gen. Ulysses S. Grant and the Confederate forces commanded by Brig. Gens. John B. Floyd, Gideon Pillow, and Simon Bolivar Buckner and resulted in a Union victory. On February 6 Grant captured Fort Henry and immediately began to move his forces to take nearby Fort Donelson, arriving on February 11. The two sides engaged in skirmishes with Grant supported by naval units commanded by Flag Officer (modern rank Rear Admiral Lower Half, RDML) Andrew H. Foote. On February 15 Confederate forces attacked Union positions with the purpose of opening an escape route to Nashville, however, Floyd recalled the Confederates to the fort without attempting escape. On the evening of February 15, Floyd and Pillow fled with a small contingent of troops. The fort was left under the command of Buckner, who on February 16, surrendered to Grant. The total number of forces engaged in the battle was 40,702; 24,531 Union and 16,171 Confederate. Casualties from the battle were estimated at 16,537 with 2,691 Union and 13,846 Confederate. The victories at Fort Henry and Fort Donelson gave the Union unchallenged access to the Tennessee and Cumberland Rivers to move troops and launch attacks into the South. The victories also put the entirety of Kentucky and most of Tennessee under Union control. (American Battlefield Trust; Wikipedia)

catDesc.term: Military Engagements--Fort Henry, Battle of, Tenn., 1862

gloss.p: The Battle of Fort Henry was fought on February 6, 1862 in Stewart and Henry Counties, Tennessee and Calloway County, Kentucky between Union land and naval forces commanded by Brig. Gen. Ulysses S. Grant and Confederate forces commanded by Brig. Gen. Lloyd Tilghman and resulted in a Union victory. On February 4 – 5 1862, Grant’s forces landed on the east bank of the Tennessee River just north of Fort Henry. On the morning of February 6, Union gunboats commanded by Flag Officer (modern rank Rear Admiral Lower Half, RDML) Andrew H. Foote opened fire on the fort. Heavy rains from the previous day flooded the fort and submerged many of its guns, impeding Tilghman’s defense. Tilghman surrendered to Foote’s flotilla. The total number of forces engaged in the battle was 17,500; 15,000 Union and 2,500 Confederate. Casualties from the battle were estimated at 63 with 42 Union and 21 Confederate. The defeat of Fort Henry, and of Fort Donelson on February 16, opened the Tennessee and Cumberland rivers for the Union to move supplies and troops and effectively put the entirety of Kentucky and most of Tennessee under Union control. (American Battlefield; Wikipedia)

gloss.p: The United States Army is the military land force of the United States of America. During the American Civil War it was also referred to as the Union Army, Federal Army, or Northern Army. Its primary military objective during the war was the restoration and preservation of the United States through the defeat of secessionist forces. The United States Army traces its roots to the Continental Army, created in 1775 during the American Revolution. Following American independence, the new United States severely reduced the size of the army due to distrust of permanent standing military forces. The small regular army generally handled military operations against Native Americans and for coastal defense. State authorities were expected to support the country’s military needs with their militias, or by raising volunteer units, temporarily activated for federal service.

At the outbreak of the Civil War, the United States regular army consisted of barely more than 16,000 soldiers, scattered across the country (primarily at coastal defenses and forts established in the territories) among ten infantry regiments, four artillery regiments, two cavalry regiments, two dragoon regiments, and one regiment of mounted rifles. Roughly 20% of the army’s officers and enlisted resigned their positions to fight for the Confederacy. After Southern troops attacked and captured Fort Sumter in South Carolina, President Abraham Lincoln called for 75,000 volunteers to expand the army and defeat the Confederates. The government continued to issue subsequent requests for volunteers as the war progressed. As with established practice, the states were to recruit the volunteers and provide them for federal service. Initial enlistments were for 90 days, but eventually enlistment terms were expanded, typically for three years. In total, more than 2,000,000 men served in the United States Army during the course of the Civil War. Of those, only around 60,000 were part of the regular army. The overwhelming majority were in state-based units. Most soldiers were volunteers, however the federal government began drafting men in 1862, as the army’s campaigns continued and volunteer numbers dwindled. In total, around 46,000 Union soldiers (about 5.5%) were draftees.

Approximately two-thirds of the soldiers in the United States Army during the Civil War were native-born white citizens. Around 100,000 were from states within the Confederacy. Immigrants made up about 25% of Union soldiers, with Germans and Irish immigrants being among the most prominent. The army also included soldiers of different ethnicities, including more than 3,000 Native American soldiers. In 1863, the Union army began formally accepting African American soldiers—in segregated units—and by the end of the war, around than 179,000 had served in the United States Army uniform.

When hostilities ended in June 1865, approximately 110,000 had been killed in combat or succumbed to wounds, more than 220,000 had died of disease, and roughly 30,000 had died in prison camps. (Wikipedia; National Park Service)

div.p: [seal]
Sageville Miss Feb 26th 1862
Hon Jno J Pettus
Dr sir

Your reply to my communi-cation of the 20th Inst came to hand to day and I hasten to make out a plan or sketch for your consideration and tho not as ample as I would wish yet I hope you will be able to discover its utility at a glance, and I shall refer you to the Diagram with but a few explanitory notes, This plan is only intended to resist a force decend-ing a river, and ^but^ you will discover that the Rafts should be anchord at both ends to resist a force ascending—First—These floats can be made of any light wood as Juniper cypress or pine and will answer better than Bouys or boats & much less expensive—they should be bolted together with iron Rods & screws horrizontally & perpendicular unless the timber can be got two feet square which would be inconvinient to handle—and Id suggest that they the floats be made 10 by 25 ft 10 ft wide & 25 ft long & at least 2 ft deep of this sollid timber which will make them ball proof and ^allso^ sloped head and stern like a skaw or common ferry boat—tho ^though^ each should be a harse hole set at a proper angle for the cable to pass thro—On these floats should be a wide windlass to regulate the stress of the main chain accross the River=and allso for the purpose of heaving foward any number of floats desired from under the main, or lage, or cross chain, in order to pass, either, drift or our own Boats—the chain sinking to a sufficient depth to admit either as soon as the floats are removed, or have foward—and here let me add that I do not mean to limit the number of these floats for the more the better, as evry additional stream cable at-tatched to the cross cable—increases materially its power of resistance where force is brot against it—

It will be necessary to have suitable fastenings on each float to secure the chain to the same whether forced under water or floating on the stream—It will allso be necessa-ry to sheild each windlass with R R or other suitable iron at such an angle as would caus a ball to glance—

The second consideration is the land fastenings which is by Pillering safely secured in a d^i^rt bank—in the absence of this or if the River bank is rocky the fastenings should be se-cured, well secured in masonry—which will be a matter of the greatest importance—

The third and last consideration of importance is the stream cables & anchors to be attatched to the floates—and Joist, the anchors should be heavy ship anchors & well beded in a gravel or mud bottom, as they would drag on a rock bottom, the cables should be of as great length as possible and as near the same length as possible—and as many as is necessary for floats to suport the cross chain near the serface of the water (for the near the the surface the better=and as before stated the more of these stream cables the stronger the cross chain, as each additional stream cable adds to the strength of the cross chain now sir after the achors are well beded in the bottom of the River—by the aid of the windlasses each ^stream^ cable can be sprung sufficient to take the heft off of the cross chain which will throw the whole arrangement upon a swing and before a decending Boat or Boats could bring the cross chain to a streach—stearage way would be lost and the Boat drift against it as a logs, and with Bat-terries planted on each side of the River—there would be but little difficulty in disposeing of our enemys as we wish—By this plan you are prepared for high or low water—Drift or no Drift whilst we avoid the abominable expedient of choking up Harbers & Rivers, and it is done on a much more sure & equinomical scale—beside a sub-
[seal]
mareene battery would hardly be necessary=while at the same time it would be entirely admissible if desired—
You Hon will allso discover that it is entirely unnessesary for ^a^ person to be exposed as no one is needed on the floats at the time of ^an^ engagement—

I can make one othe suggestion which would make everything doubly secure—which will be to add another similar obstruction just above and within cannon shot of of the Batterries which would afford our forces a double opertunity=

Now sir let me say in conclusion that in this we have no gaudy show—no grand display of arms—no costly array—trusting alone to God and our own resorces for our preservavtion—whilst at the same time our forces may be made secure behind such works as our military officers may see fit to d^i^rect—praying allways that God will save us from any more Fts Henrys & Donnalsons to depend us from such ruthless foes—and if in this I can add to your Honour or to my Countrys Independ-ance or even save a city from the hell hounds that seek our subjugation Im amply paid. Moreover if my services are needed to carry out this plan Im at your service, tho my domestic concerns may suffer—for so well am I satisfied of its practicability had I have had the means to have gone to Jackson and Richmond I would have in person laid my plans before you & secretary Walker last October—

with evry Consideration
of Respect & Esteem—
I am sir Yours Resply

From
E. J Reed—
1862
